Comment: I kick off the game with a standard e4.
My opponent plays the Caro-Kann, which is a relatively safe opening for black. Black prepares a d5 push in order to contest my e4 pawn.

The usual move here is 2.d4, but I had some other plans in mind. I wanted to throw him a little off game. The main downside of this move is that it opens the g1-a7 diagonal, which could prove troublesome.
Black follows his plans, and strikes at the center.
!? Yes, I'm leaving my e pawn ripe for the taking while also allowing my opponent to poke check my knight. However, White can either recover that lost pawn or get a huge attack.
Black obliges, and chases my knight away.
I move my knight into safety and I attack the pawn.
Black plays the most natural move which develops a piece and protects his advanced e pawn. 4...f5 is dubious, because of 5.Bc4 (attacking f7) Nh6 6.Nxh7!? Rxh7 7.Qh5+ Kd7 8.Qg6.
! This is not exactly what I'd call subtle, but the attack on f7 has to be dealt with. Or does it?
Well, much to my dismay, my opponent went for the safe route. The risky but still playable other option was 5...Bg4!? 6.Qxg4! Nxg4 7.Bxf7+ Kd7 8.Be6+ Kc7 9.Bxg4 and the position is very unclear.
I hit Black's advanced e pawn once more. It is attacked twice and defended once.
Black decides to give back the pawn and develops his bishop on the g1-a7 diagonal, preventing me to castle kingside.
I think either recapture is fine.
Black tucks his bishop into safety, while keeping an eye on that pesky diagonal.
I free my bishop while reinforcing my advanced pieces.
Black castles.
I move my queen out of the back rank, allowing me to eventually castle queeside. This also give me the option to play 10.Be3 to exchange bishops.
Good move. It would be very troublesome if the e file was to open...
I plan to play 11.f5 after black tries to open the middle with 10...e5. Even if he doesn't, my rook could jump to f3 into g3 or h3.
Black puts his knight on a strong square. It cannot be taken due to the discovered attack/pin on the e file.
